gurmukhi: Ary jy su mwry ] imly qy ju hwry ] ley srb sMgM ] rsy rIJ rMgM ]488]
transliteration: Are Je Su Mdare|| Mile Te Ju Hdare|| Lae Sarab Sanadg|| Rase Reejh Ranadg||488||
translation: He, who resisted before them, was killed and he, who was defeated, he surrendered; in this way, all were delightfully adjusted.488.

gurmukhi: dieE dwn eyqo ] kQy k`ib kyqo ] irJy srb rwjw ] bjy bMb bwjw ]489]
transliteration: Daeo Daan Eto|| Kathe Kabb(i) Keto|| Rijhe Sarab Raajaa|| Bade Banb Baajaa||489||
translation: So much charity was bestowed, that they can only be described by the poets; all the kings became happy and the horns of victory sounded.489.

gurmukhi: Kurwsn jIqw ] sBhUM sMg lIqw ] dieE Awp mMqRM ] Bly Aaur jMqRM ]490]
transliteration: Khuraasan Jitaa|| Sabh-hoon San Litaa|| Daeo Aap Mantran|| Bhale Aur Jantran||
translation: The Khorasan country was conquered and taking every-one with him, the Lord (Kalki) gave his mantra and Yantra to everyone.490.

gurmukhi: cilE dY ngwrw ] imilE sYn Bwrw ] kiRpwxI inKMgM ] skRoDI BVMgM ]491]
transliteration: Chadio Dai Nagadraa|| Milio Sain Bhaaraa|| Kridaaninikhanndan|| Sakrodhibhadanadg||491||
translation: From there, sounding trumpets and taking all the army alongwith him he marched forward; the warriors had the swords and quivers; they were extremely angry and clashing warriors.491.

gurmukhi: BUA kMpq jMpq SyS PxM ] GhrMq su GuMGr Gor rxM ] sr q`jq g`jq kRoD juDM ] muK mwr aucwr juJwr kRuDM ]492]
transliteration: Bhooa Kanpat Janpat Shesh Phanan|| Ghahrant Su Ghounghar Ghor Ranan|| Sar Tajjat Gadjat Krodh Judhan|| Moukh Maar Ouchaar Jujhaar Kudhan||492||
translation: The earth trembled and the Sheshnaga repeated Lord’s Names; the dreadful bells of war rang; the warriors in ire discharged arrows and shouted “kill, kill” from their mouth.492.

gurmukhi: biRx J`lq G`lq Gwie GxM ] kV ku`t sup`Kr bRK rxM ] gix ig`D su biRD rVMq nBM ] iklkwrq fwkx au`c surM ]493]
transliteration: Brin Jhallat Ghallat Ghaae Ghanan|| Kad Koutt Soupakkhar Brakh Radan|| Gad(i) Giddh Su Briddh Radant Nabhan|| Kilkaarat Daakan Ouchch Suran||493||
translation: Enduring the anguish of wounds, they began to inflict wounds and cut the good steel-armours in the battlefield; the ghosts and the vultures moved in the sky and the vampires shrieked vultures moved in the sky and the vampires shrieked violently.493.

gurmukhi: gix hUr supUr iPrI ggxM ] Avlok sbwih lgI SrxM ] muK Bwvq gwvq gIq surI ] gx pUr sup`Kr hUr iPrI ]494]
transliteration: Gad(i) Hoor Soupoor Phirigadanan|| Avlok Sahaah(i) Lagi Sharanan|| Moukh Bhaavat Gadvat Geet Suree|| Gad Poor Soupakkhar Hoor Phiree||494||
translation: The heavenly damsels moved in the sky and they came to look for and take refuge with the warriors in the battlefield, they sang song from their mouths and in this way, the ganas and heavenly damsels roamed in the sky.496.

gurmukhi: Bt pyKq poAq hwr hrI ] hhrwvq hws iPrI pKrI ] dl gwhq bwhq bIr biRxM ] pRx pUr su p`Cs jIq rxM ]495]
transliteration: Bhat Pekhat Poat Haar Daree|| Hahraavat Haas Phiripakhree|| Dal Gadhat Baahat Beer Brinan|| Pran Poor Su Pachchham Jit Ranan||495||
translation: Seeing the warriors, Shiva began to string the rosary of skulls and Yoginis laughed and moved; the fighters, roaming in the armies received wounds and in this way they began to fulfill their promise of conquering the West.495.

gurmukhi: jIq srb p`Cm idSw d`Cn kIn iDAwn ] ijm ijm ju`D qhw prw iqm iqm kroN bKwn ]496]
transliteration: Jit Sarab Pachchham Dishaa Dachchhan Keen Dhiaan|| Jim Jim Juddh Tahaa Paraa Tim Tim Daron Bakhaan||496||
translation: Conquering the whole of the west, Kalki thought of moving towards the South and I do not relate the wars, that occurred there.496.

gurmukhi: rx jMpq ju`gx jUh jXM ] kl kMpq BIr ABIr BXM ] hV h`sq h`sq hws miRVw ] fl fols SMkq SyS iQrw ]497]
transliteration: Ran Janpat Judgad Jooh Jayan|| Kal Kanpat Bhdr Abheer Bhayan|| Had Hassat Hassat Haas Mridaa|| Dal Dolas Shankat Shesh Thiraa||497||
translation: Remembering the war, the Yoginis are hailing and the trembling cowards of the Iron Age also became fearless; the hags are laughing violently and Sheshnaga, getting dubious, is wavering.497.
